trans-unit.source: Administering a Mobile Service from the command line | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Administering a Mobile Service from the command line | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create, deploy, and manage your Azure Mobile Service using command-line tools.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create, deploy, and manage your Azure Mobile Service using command-line tools.

trans-unit.source: Automate mobile services with command-line tools
trans-unit.target: Automate mobile services with command-line tools

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use the Azure command-line tools to automate the creation and management of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use the Azure command-line tools to automate the creation and management of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to install and get started using the command-line tools and use them to perform key Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to install and get started using the command-line tools and use them to perform key Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: When combined into a single script or batch file, these individual commands automate the creation, verification, and deletion process of a mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When combined into a single script or batch file, these individual commands automate the creation, verification, and deletion process of a mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This topic covers a selection of common administration tasks supported by the Azure command-line tools.
trans-unit.target: This topic covers a selection of common administration tasks supported by the Azure command-line tools.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure command-line tools documentation][reference-docs].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure command-line tools documentation][reference-docs].

trans-unit.source: Install the Azure Command-Line Tools
trans-unit.target: Install the Azure Command-Line Tools

trans-unit.source: The following list contains information for installing the command-line tools, depending on your operating system:
trans-unit.target: The following list contains information for installing the command-line tools, depending on your operating system:

trans-unit.source: **Windows**: Download the [Azure Command-Line Tools Installer][windows-installer].
trans-unit.target: **Windows**: Download the [Azure Command-Line Tools Installer][windows-installer].

trans-unit.source: Open the downloaded .msi file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.
trans-unit.target: Open the downloaded .msi file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.

trans-unit.source: **Mac**: Download the [Azure SDK Installer][mac-installer].
trans-unit.target: **Mac**: Download the [Azure SDK Installer][mac-installer].

trans-unit.source: Open the downloaded .pkg file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.
trans-unit.target: Open the downloaded .pkg file and complete the installation steps as you are prompted.

trans-unit.source: **Linux**: Install the latest version of [Node.js][nodejs-org] (see [Install Node.js via Package Manager][install-node-linux]), then run the following command:
trans-unit.target: **Linux**: Install the latest version of [Node.js][nodejs-org] (see [Install Node.js via Package Manager][install-node-linux]), then run the following command:

trans-unit.source: npm install azure-cli -g
trans-unit.target: npm install azure-cli -g

trans-unit.source: To test the installation, type `azure` at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To test the installation, type `azure` at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: When the installation is successful, you will see a list of all the available `azure` commands.
trans-unit.target: When the installation is successful, you will see a list of all the available `azure` commands.

trans-unit.source: How to download and import publish settings
trans-unit.target: How to download and import publish settings

trans-unit.source: To get started, you must first download and import your publish settings.
trans-unit.target: To get started, you must first download and import your publish settings.

trans-unit.source: Then you can use the tools to create and manage Azure Services.
trans-unit.target: Then you can use the tools to create and manage Azure Services.

trans-unit.source: To download your publish settings, use the `account download` command:
trans-unit.target: To download your publish settings, use the `account download` command:

trans-unit.source: This opens your default browser and prompts you to sign in to the Azure classic portal.
trans-unit.target: This opens your default browser and prompts you to sign in to the Azure classic portal.

trans-unit.source: After signing in, your `.publishsettings` file is downloaded.
trans-unit.target: After signing in, your `.publishsettings` file is downloaded.

trans-unit.source: Note the location of this saved file.
trans-unit.target: Note the location of this saved file.

trans-unit.source: Next, import the `.publishsettings` file by running the following command, replacing `<path-to-settings-file>` with the path to your `.publishsettings` file:
trans-unit.target: Next, import the `.publishsettings` file by running the following command, replacing `<path-to-settings-file>` with the path to your `.publishsettings` file:

trans-unit.source: You can remove all of the information stored by the
trans-unit.target: You can remove all of the information stored by the

trans-unit.source: import
trans-unit.target: import

trans-unit.source: command by using the
trans-unit.target: command by using the

trans-unit.source: account clear
trans-unit.target: account clear

trans-unit.source: command:
trans-unit.target: command:

trans-unit.source: To see a list of options for `account` commands, use the `-help` option:
trans-unit.target: To see a list of options for `account` commands, use the `-help` option:

trans-unit.source: After importing your publish settings, you should delete the `.publishsettings` file for security reasons.
trans-unit.target: After importing your publish settings, you should delete the `.publishsettings` file for security reasons.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to install the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to install the Azure Command-Line Tools for Mac and Linux].

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to begin creating and managing Azure Mobile Services from the command line or in batch files.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to begin creating and managing Azure Mobile Services from the command line or in batch files.

trans-unit.source: How to create a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to create a mobile service

trans-unit.source: You can use the command-line tools to create a new mobile service instance.
trans-unit.target: You can use the command-line tools to create a new mobile service instance.

trans-unit.source: While creating the mobile service, you also create a SQL Database instance in a new server.
trans-unit.target: While creating the mobile service, you also create a SQL Database instance in a new server.

trans-unit.source: The following command creates a new mobile service instance in your subscription, where `<service-name>` is the name of the new mobile service, `<server-admin>` is the login name of the new server, and `<server-password>` is the password for the new login:
trans-unit.target: The following command creates a new mobile service instance in your subscription, where `<service-name>` is the name of the new mobile service, `<server-admin>` is the login name of the new server, and `<server-password>` is the password for the new login:

trans-unit.source: The `mobile create` command fails when the specified mobile service exists.
trans-unit.target: The `mobile create` command fails when the specified mobile service exists.

trans-unit.source: In your automation scripts, you should attempt to delete a mobile service before attempting to recreate it.
trans-unit.target: In your automation scripts, you should attempt to delete a mobile service before attempting to recreate it.

trans-unit.source: How to list existing mobile services in a subscription
trans-unit.target: How to list existing mobile services in a subscription

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Commands in the CLI related to "list" and "script" only work with the JavaScript backend.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Commands in the CLI related to "list" and "script" only work with the JavaScript backend.

trans-unit.source: The following command returns a list of all the mobile services in an Azure subscription:
trans-unit.target: The following command returns a list of all the mobile services in an Azure subscription:

trans-unit.source: This command also shows the current state and URL of each mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This command also shows the current state and URL of each mobile service.

trans-unit.source: How to delete an existing mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to delete an existing mobile service

trans-unit.source: You can use the command-line tools to delete an existing mobile service, along with the related SQL Database and server.
trans-unit.target: You can use the command-line tools to delete an existing mobile service, along with the related SQL Database and server.

trans-unit.source: The following command deletes the mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service to delete:
trans-unit.target: The following command deletes the mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service to delete:

trans-unit.source: By including `-a` and `-q` parameters, this command also deletes the SQL Database and server used by the mobile service without displaying a prompt.
trans-unit.target: By including `-a` and `-q` parameters, this command also deletes the SQL Database and server used by the mobile service without displaying a prompt.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not specify the -q parameter along with -a or -d, execution is paused and you are prompted to select delete options for your SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not specify the -q parameter along with -a or -d, execution is paused and you are prompted to select delete options for your SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Only use the -a parameter when no other service uses the database or server; otherwise use the -d parameter to only delete data that belongs to the mobile service being deleted.
trans-unit.target: Only use the -a parameter when no other service uses the database or server; otherwise use the -d parameter to only delete data that belongs to the mobile service being deleted.

trans-unit.source: How to create a table in the mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to create a table in the mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following command creates a table in the specified mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service and `<table-name>` is the name of the table to create:
trans-unit.target: The following command creates a table in the specified mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service and `<table-name>` is the name of the table to create:

trans-unit.source: This creates a new table with the default permissions, `application`, for the table operations: `insert`, `read`, `update`, and `delete`.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new table with the default permissions, `application`, for the table operations: `insert`, `read`, `update`, and `delete`.

trans-unit.source: The following command creates a new table with public `read` permission but with `delete` permission granted only to administrators:
trans-unit.target: The following command creates a new table with public `read` permission but with `delete` permission granted only to administrators:

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the script permission value compared to the permission value in the [Azure classic portal].
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the script permission value compared to the permission value in the [Azure classic portal].

trans-unit.source: |Script value|Portal value| |========|========| |`public`|Everyone| |`application`(default)|Anybody with the application key| |`user`|Only authenticated users| |`admin`|Only scripts and admins|
trans-unit.target: |Script value|Portal value| |========|========| |`public`|Everyone| |`application`(default)|Anybody with the application key| |`user`|Only authenticated users| |`admin`|Only scripts and admins|

trans-unit.source: The `mobile table create` command fails when the specified table already exists.
trans-unit.target: The `mobile table create` command fails when the specified table already exists.

trans-unit.source: In your automation scripts, you should attempt to delete a table before attempting to recreate it.
trans-unit.target: In your automation scripts, you should attempt to delete a table before attempting to recreate it.

trans-unit.source: How to list existing tables in a mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to list existing tables in a mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following command returns a list of all of the tables in a mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service:
trans-unit.target: The following command returns a list of all of the tables in a mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service:

trans-unit.source: This command also shows the number of indexes on each table and the number of data rows currently in the table.
trans-unit.target: This command also shows the number of indexes on each table and the number of data rows currently in the table.

trans-unit.source: How to delete an existing table from the mobile service
trans-unit.target: How to delete an existing table from the mobile service

trans-unit.source: The following command deletes a table from the mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service and `<table-name>` is the name of the table to delete:
trans-unit.target: The following command deletes a table from the mobile service, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service and `<table-name>` is the name of the table to delete:

trans-unit.source: In automation scripts, use the `-q` parameter to delete the table without displaying a confirmation prompt that blocks execution.
trans-unit.target: In automation scripts, use the `-q` parameter to delete the table without displaying a confirmation prompt that blocks execution.

trans-unit.source: How to register a script to a table operation
trans-unit.target: How to register a script to a table operation

trans-unit.source: The following command uploads and registers a function to an operation on a table, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service, `<table-name>` is the name of the table, and `<operation>` is the table operation, which can be `read`, `insert`, `update`, or `delete`:
trans-unit.target: The following command uploads and registers a function to an operation on a table, where `<service-name>` is the name of the mobile service, `<table-name>` is the name of the table, and `<operation>` is the table operation, which can be `read`, `insert`, `update`, or `delete`:

trans-unit.source: Note that this operation uploads a JavaScript (.js) file from the local computer.
trans-unit.target: Note that this operation uploads a JavaScript (.js) file from the local computer.

trans-unit.source: The name of the file must be composed from the table and operation names, and it must be located in the `table` subfolder relative to the location where the command is executed.
trans-unit.target: The name of the file must be composed from the table and operation names, and it must be located in the `table` subfolder relative to the location where the command is executed.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following operation uploads and registers a new `insert` script that belongs to the `TodoItems` table:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following operation uploads and registers a new `insert` script that belongs to the `TodoItems` table:

trans-unit.source: The function declaration in the script file must also match the registered table operation.
trans-unit.target: The function declaration in the script file must also match the registered table operation.

trans-unit.source: This means that for an `insert` script, the uploaded script contains a function with the following signature:
trans-unit.target: This means that for an `insert` script, the uploaded script contains a function with the following signature:

trans-unit.source: For more information about registering scripts, see [Mobile Services server script reference].
trans-unit.target: For more information about registering scripts, see [Mobile Services server script reference].
